703868f-a.text:
Cranberry Street, south side, between Henry and Hicks Street showing the old Plymouth Church, built in 1849, from which Henry Ward Beecher preached his sermons. A brass plate in the church marks the pew where Abraham Lincoln, who was a personal friend of the Brooklyn preacher, sat to hear his sermons. The edifice extends through to Orange Street.
See Orange Street file for other views and "The New York
Times," October 5, 1940, for additional data.
1922
Views 1,2
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
703868f-a.folder: Cranberry Street & Henry Street, Brooklyn, NY

704827f-a.text:
Henry Street, east side, south from Cranberry Street. The peaked front 3-story building in the foreground, was the former Firemen's Hall.
It was erected about 1851.
1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Cellection.
704827f-a.folder: Henry Street & Cranberry Street, Brooklyn, NY

704824f-a.text:
42-50 Henry Street, west side, north from Cranberry Street, as seen across 1ot at the N.E. corner of Henry and Ceanberry Streets.
February 5, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

704826f-a.text:
Henry Street, at the S.W. corner of Cranberry Street, showing building under construction. Also seen is a building at 50 Henry Street, at the
N.W. corner of Cranberry Street.
February 5, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
704826f-a.folder: Henry Street & Cranberry Street, Brooklyn, NY

703867f-a.text:
Cranberry Street, south side, from Henry to Fulton Streets. In the background, is Fulton Street, east side, south from High Street, with its
B.M.T. Elevated Lines.
April 4, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
703867f-a.folder: Cranberry Street & Henry Street, Brooklyn, NY

704843f-a.text:
240-246 Henry Street, at, adjoining and north of the N.W. corner. No. 240, is the house at the extreme right. Also seen is Cranberry Street,
north side, west of Henry Street.
April 1, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
704843f-a.folder: Henry Street & Cranberry Street, Brooklyn, NY

703869f-a.text:
Cranberry Street, south side, between Henry and Hicks Streets, viewing west from near Henry Street and showing the Plymouth Church, from which the famous Brooklvn preacher Henry Ward eecher delivered his sermons. The church was built in 1849 and extends through to Orange Street. The three-story house with the brownstone stoop, to the left of the church, is Henry Ward Beecher's old home and President Abraham Lincoln and General Ulysses S. Grant are ssid to have visited here. The house is No. 66 Cranberry Street and was remodelled, in 1940, into an apartment hose for five families. For additional
data see "The New York Times," October 5, 1940.
View 1: Eugene L. Armbruster Collection  1922
View 2: P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS  April 5, 1938
703869f-a.folder: Cranberry Street & Henry Street, Brooklyn, NY

Cranberry Street, south side, between Henry and Hicks Streets, viewing west from near Henry Street and showing the Plymouth Church, from which the famous Brooklvn preacher Henry Ward eecher delivered his sermons. The church was built in 1849 and extends through to Orange Street. The three-story house with the brownstone stoop, to the left of the church, is Henry Ward Beecher's old home and President Abraham Lincoln and General Ulysses S. Grant are ssid to have visited here. 703869f-b.folder: Cranberry Street & Henry Street, Brooklyn, NY

703870f-a.text:
Cranberry Street, south side, between Henry and Hicks Streets, showing the old Plymouth Church, built in 1849 and made famous by its preacher Henry Ward Beecher. A brass plate in the church marks the pew where Abraham Lincoln, a personal friend of the minister, sat to hear his sermons. The first three-story brownstone house, to the left of the church, is Henry Ward Beecher's old home, No. 66 Cranberry Street, and the Civil War President and General 'lysses S. Erant are said to have visited here. In 1940 the house was transformed into a five-family apartment house.
View 1 is east from Hicks Street; views 2 and 3, west from Henry Street. For additional data see "The New York Times," October
5, 1940.
Views 1,2: Eugene L. Armbruster Collection  1925
View 3: P. L. Sperr  February 3, 1931
703870f-a.folder: Cranberry Street & Henry Street, Brooklyn, NY

A brass plate in the church marks the pew where Abraham Lincoln, a personal friend of the minister, sat to hear his sermons. The first three-story brownstone house, to the left of the church, is Henry Ward Beecher's old home, No. 66 Cranberry Street, and the Civil War President and General 'lysses S. Erant are said to have visited here. In 1940 the house was transformed into a five-family apartment house.
View 1 is east from Hicks Street; views 2 and 3, west from Henry Street. For additional data see "The New York Times," October
5, 1940.

704822f-a.text:
(1)
32-40 Henry Street, west side, north from Cranberry to Middagh Streets. Three buildings in the foreground, are frame with conposition fronts.
November 1, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, but showing Middagh Street, south side, west from Henry Street. The foreground shows 3 frame buildings with composition fronts. The corner building in 1927 housed a bar which was closed
by the U.S. District Court.
February 5, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, an earlier view
i922
E. L. Armbruster Cgllection.
